steps.title: Try to find out how old the wood piece or furniture is.
steps.content: Try to find out how old the wood piece or furniture is. Shellac was a common wood finish before the 1920s; this may be enough to indicate to you that you have a shellac finish. Shellac is also the principal way to make French polish and has been used for this purpose on quality furniture over the past century. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Test for a shellac finish.
steps.content: Test for a shellac finish. Old or new, here is the way to check the finish on the furniture or woodwork: [4] X Research source Dab a little denatured alcohol or lacquer thinner on one section of the wood finish. Try to find an inconspicuous spot. [5] X Expert Source William & Shannon Latil Furniture Refinishing & Home Remodeling Specialists Expert Interview. 29 October 2021. If it is shellac finish, it will liquefy and dissolve. [6] X Research source You know it's a lacquer finish if the test spot turns a little white in color. [7] X Expert Source William & Shannon Latil Furniture Refinishing & Home Remodeling Specialists Expert Interview. 29 October 2021. A result of softening without dissolving suggests there is shellac present but that it has been mixed with lacquer as well. Any other response and you're probably looking at a different wood finish. If in doubt, talk to someone familiar with furniture restoration.

steps.title: Work to avoid jobs rather than create them when restoring furniture and woodwork!
steps.content: Work to avoid jobs rather than create them when restoring furniture and woodwork! Where the shellac finish appears stained or has dirt embedded in it, try the following first: [8] X Research source Sprinkle a mild abrasive compound over the surface. For example, pumice or rotten-stone. Work this in. Rub off with a cloth.

steps.title: Buff with a clean rag.
steps.content: Buff with a clean rag. If the surface looks good again, you're spared having to remove the shellac.

steps.title: Use denatured alcohol to remove shellac.
steps.content: Use denatured alcohol to remove shellac. [9] X Research source Also find a piece of 4/0 steel wool.

steps.title: Using a small brush, brush the shellac with the denatured alcohol.
steps.content: Using a small brush, brush the shellac with the denatured alcohol.

steps.title: Allow the denatured alcohol to sit for a few minutes.
steps.content: Allow the denatured alcohol to sit for a few minutes. This will help it to begin naturally stripping off the shellac. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Put on some rubber gloves to protect your hands.
steps.content: Put on some rubber gloves to protect your hands. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Rub the shellac with the steel wool.
steps.content: Rub the shellac with the steel wool. Remove as much as you can with the steel wool. This part does require some effort and hard rubbing. You may need to take breaks and come back to it, depending on the size of the job. Getting others to help is always a good solution!

steps.title: Use a carpet knife for curved, grooved or harder areas.
steps.content: Use a carpet knife for curved, grooved or harder areas. This will be able to reach into narrow spots where the steel wool is just not able to reach.

steps.title: Remove the remaining shellac by wiping with a rag.
steps.content: Remove the remaining shellac by wiping with a rag. Change the rag frequently, to avoid reapplying the shellac on stripped parts of the surface.

steps.title: Remove all soft pieces and any debris before proceeding with adding a new finish.
steps.content: Remove all soft pieces and any debris before proceeding with adding a new finish. It's also important to sand the surface before applying a new finish. [12] X Research source
